I am writing to formally raise a complaint about the exceptionally poor service I have received, particularly from the Milton Keynes branch, as a loyal Vodafone customer of 10 years. The series of issues I have faced over the past several months has been incredibly frustrating, time-consuming, and ultimately unresolved.I initially began experiencing service issues in August 2024, when I had no access to my phone for two weeks. However, despite the fact that the account is in my name and the phone belongs to me, I was informed that no action could be taken because my father pays for the service. My father, who is 68 years old and suffers from dementia, Parkinson‚Äôs, and poor mobility, is unable to leave the house easily. Even after explaining this, the staff at the MK branch offered no apology or assistance, and I was sent away without a resolution.The following week, I had no choice but to bring my father into the store in a wheelchair to update the account and receive a new SIM card, which should have been done in the first place. This issue was somewhat resolved for a short period, but in December 2024, my service dropped once again, this time for a more extended period.On December 28, 2024, my service dropped again and did not return. I returned to the MK branch, where I was told that the issue was hardware-related, not the SIM card. I was assured by both Sunny and another store manager that I would not incur any charges for repairs, and it was suggested that I return in the new year to send off the phone for repairs, as this would be quicker.I returned on January 7, 2025, to send the phone off for repair. I was assisted by Avril, who seemed unsure of the process and stated that she "wasn‚Äôt very good at this." After some assistance from the store manager, I was informed that my warranty had expired just a week prior to my visit. I inquired if there was any possibility of disputing the repair charges, as I had previously visited the store within my warranty period, and was assured by Sunny that everything would be handled, and I should not worry. However, the interaction felt rushed and dismissive, especially as the store was nearing closing time.On January 17, 2025, I received my phone back in the mail, still broken, along with a letter stating that the repair could not be completed due to the warranty expiry. The letter also mentioned that they had attempted to contact me, but I have not received any emails or messages regarding this matter. This is entirely unacceptable. I am now left without a working phone and still being billed for the service.I am deeply dissatisfied with the entire process, the lack of communication, and the ongoing inconvenience this has caused. I have invested a significant amount of time visiting the store, engaging in live chats, and speaking on the phone, only to be left with no resolution and no confidence in the repair process. I was assured multiple times that this issue would be resolved, but I am now at square one, with no solution in sight.As part of the resolution to this matter, I would appreciate a full refund for the two-week period in August 2024 when I had no access to my phone, as was initially promised. Additionally, I request that this issue be escalated to ensure a proper resolution, including repair or replacement of my phone at no cost, given the ongoing nature of the problem and the significant delays caused by Vodafone's lack of communication and support.Please consider this letter a formal complaint. If this matter is not resolved promptly, I will be forced to take further action, including escalating the complaint to the relevant regulatory bodies. Should this issue be resolved, please be assured that I will be discontinuing my relationship with Vodafone after 10 years of service.I look forward to your prompt response.Sincerely,Chloe MayockAnthony Mayock

The main complaint I have with Vodafone UK is their poor service, specifically regarding buffering and latency issues. After months of frustration, I bought a third-party router (TP-Link Deco) which finally resolved the issues, proving that the fault was with the router provided by Vodafone. Despite this, Vodafone refused to send a replacement router or send someone to test the equipment. Their boosters and routers are of very poor quality, and I strongly recommend avoiding them. Instead, invest in a reliable router like TP-Link Deco or Eero and use the PPPoE account provided by Vodafone rather than their subpar devices.From the outset, Vodafone‚Äôs service has been appalling. When I first signed up, they never bothered to send anyone to properly set up the connection. Aside from the Openreach engineer installing the fibre, I had to do everything else myself. Despite reporting multiple issues, Vodafone repeatedly came up with different excuses for the poor service. At various times, they blamed congestion, my house, the number of devices I was using, or even the fact that I tested the internet on iPhones rather than Android devices. I was told to make video calls to show the cable I was using‚Äîeven though I was using a high-quality Cat 8 cable.Despite all of this, no one from Vodafone ever came to my address to properly investigate the issue. Instead, I was left dealing with a support team that appeared to lack any knowledge of broadband or technical troubleshooting. I‚Äôve had to waste hours on the phone, often during the day when I‚Äôm at work, and was still left with no resolution.Even after I reported the case to CISAS, Vodafone continued to be inconsistent. They emailed me stating I would not have to pay a termination fee, yet every time I tried to cancel, they insisted I would be charged ¬£70 for the remaining three months. This lack of accountability is unacceptable.To make matters worse, when I asked for email responses instead of phone calls, their standard reply was to offer another 24-month contract, with no credit or reimbursement for the time I paid for non-functional devices.For anyone considering Vodafone broadband, I strongly advise against it. If you‚Äôre looking for a reliable provider, check out Zen, Cuckoo, or Utility Warehouse, and focus on Openreach providers with better reviews. Avoid Vodafone‚Äôs devices entirely‚Äîuse your own router with a PPPoE account, which is easy to set up and far more reliable.Additional Advice: If you‚Äôre considering Wi-Fi 6E or Wi-Fi 7, make sure you have the latest devices in your home (e.g., iPhone 16, the latest MacBook, or top-tier Lenovo laptops) to fully utilise these technologies. Otherwise, they‚Äôre not worth it.To Vodafone: Please do not respond with a generic ‚Äúcontact us to discuss‚Äù reply. Every time I‚Äôve contacted you, I‚Äôve been stonewalled, ignored, or offered unhelpful solutions. Your customer service is the worst I‚Äôve ever experienced.Update 13.01.25: Vodafone reached an agreement, and I received a credit as compensation. A new contract has been established without any additional boosters, offering a favourable monthly rate.

In essence, they incorrectly charged me, took my money and then said they couldn't do anything to put it right. However, let me take you on a journey of poor customer service:I was billed mid-December for a broadband service that was not even due to be connected until 7 January. I contacted their customer service rep who told me it was a technical error, it would be resolved without me doing any more and they definitely would not take my money.They took my money.I logged on to my account and tried to connect to customer service. It needed to verify who I was (despite me having logged in) and offered to send a verification code. It then refused to send a verification code as I didn't have a Vodfone mobile. Instead I had to enter my account id and password again.I was then through to the AI chatbot - artificial certainly, intelligent not at all. It refused to accept this was a problem it could not resolve and we ended up going round in circles with the dunce bot sending me a copy of the bill several times and insisting it could explain it. In the end, I explicitly asked to be connected with a real person. This is did after a few more inane questions to get me to the "right" person.I explained the problem to the real person. Who asked me to confirm that I had no broadband from them. A point they should have known and eventually went on to accept.This took an enormous length of time as the real person replied very slowly (presumably juggling to many enquiries at once). Speed of response was so slow that the dunce bot kept interjecting with threats to terminate the conversation, even though it was the rep that was failing to respond.The rep tried to excuse the charge on the basis that I was paying for a landline connection. For a host of different reasons, this was nonsense. So they lied about not taking the money and then lied about the reason for the charge.Finally, it was acknowledged the bill had been issued in error. I thought light could be seen at the end of the tunnel. However, even though the bill should not have been issued and the money should not have been taken, the rep said they could do nothing about it. They had no power to issue a credit note against the bill or to return my money! This from the person the dunce bot had connected me to because of an ability to resolve billing issues.After fruitless and slow further discussion which just served to make me angry, I asked to be connected to a supervisor/manager. The rep said there was no point as the supervisor had the same powers an would just say the same thing!I asked if there was a formal complaints procedure/contact. This question was not answered.I decided to abandon the call and see, for the first time in my life, whether the direct debit guarantee scheme would offer an avenue to get my money back.I was offered an email with a transcript of the call. I thought this might be useful so accepted. It asked for my email yet again. Unsurprisingly the the transcript was never sent (yes, I checked junk.)In the unlikely event anyone reads this far, sorry for the long review; just needed to get it off my chest.UPDATE: Found their formal complaints procedure. It was impressively efficient and sorted everything out very quickly. It is a shame it had to come to that.

The next day, nothing happened, although I was supposed to get a follow-up call between 1 and 3 pm. Called at 3 pm, and still no photos, if I could send them again. This happened, and I was told the specialist team would now be in touch within 4 hours. After 2 hours, att 6 pm last night, I got a text from the specialist team that an internal team would not look into my fault and that it could take until today for an update to be provided. The customer support employee from last night promised me a call this morning, which unfortunately did not happen. Instead, I got my first bill claiming money for the service that is supposedly been running smoothly since Monday and although I had been promised that I would only be charged from when the connection is succesfully established and I would be entitled to compensation as well. A falling branch knocked down the fibre line near my property on the 24th November. I reported the fault immediately to the customer service team. It is now 16th December. I have made ten calls to the customer service team, had seven different Openreach engineers visit, been given three different dates to put the cable back up and still the cable has not been reconnected. The first engineer told me that a pole might need to be replaced but a temporary repair could be done in the meantime and would take about an hour. Still the cable has not been reconnected. We are pensioners living in rural Wales and rely heavily on this service as our telephone is VOIP and therefore not working either. Our mobile service is patchy at best and we are concerned that we are now facing Christmas unable to connect with family and friends. The customer service approach is hamstrung by adherence to script and distance from the problem and despite escalating the complaint to a manager we have made no headway whatsoever. I am sick and tired of being told how sorry everybody is for these are just words to dismiss me when what is needed is action to remedy the problem. This level of customer service is deplorable for a global company and I will certainly consider my options when contract renewal is due.I am writing an update to my review having seen the reply from Vodafone. If the respondent had read the review more carefully I made it clear that the fault was reported on 24th November. Storm Darragh occurred on 7th December. That gave a window of two clear working weeks to take action and rectify the problem. Even if a specialist team was needed to put in a new pole, a temporary repair could have been effected to keep us online and this opportunity was not followed up. I have now had four dates promised and passed and I still have no internet or phone. The call count to the customer service line is now up to thirteen and a total of seven hours spent trying to get an answer to this problem. All I keep hearing is "we are waiting for an update from Openreach". I have escalated the complaint once again and am now told that someone will be in touch within the next seven days. I cannot help but reflect that if my monthly direct debit had been refused the action would have been far more swift and robust. This whole episode is an absolute masterclass in how to irritate and alienate paying customers who rely on a service which is not being provided. Maybe if the customer service was more focused it would not be necessary to have a team monitoring social media to deflect and excuse poor reviews.

When I contacted Vodafone, I was told CityFibre hadn‚Äôt completed the job for my address. After several calls, I was advised to wait three days for their Artificial Intelligence system to fix the issue‚Äîan absolute joke!On Wednesday, 11th December, a CityFibre engineer called, claiming to be outside my house. However, he was confused and accidentally contacted the wrong customer. When he did arrive, he found that my ONT box hadn‚Äôt been provisioned properly during installation. This explained the intermittent service. He resolved it, but on Thursday, 12th December, the internet went down again at 8am.The back-and-forth between Vodafone and CityFibre has been exhausting. Diagnostics tests were run over and over, but the problem persisted‚Äîa flashing red alarm light on the fibre box.To make matters worse, I bumped into a CityFibre engineer on the road, and he confirmed the ONT boxes in my area needed replacing. However, he couldn‚Äôt proceed because Vodafone hadn‚Äôt submitted the necessary report. Vodafone also refuses to confirm conversations or actions by email, citing internal policies.Despite being within the 14-day cooling-off period, Vodafone has made it nearly impossible to cancel my contract, claiming their system won‚Äôt allow it.I‚Äôm sharing this to raise awareness about the appalling service from both Vodafone and CityFibre. The external work was completed in preparation for the installation inside my flat, initially scheduled for Friday, 8th November 2024.1) On Tuesday, 5th November 2024, at 15:36, I received a text from Vodafone informing me that both my order and the engineer appointment had been cancelled.2) Upon investigation, I learned that a neighbour had lodged a complaint about a City Fibre engineer allegedly using an unauthorised key to access the building. This matter had nothing to do with my order.3) City Fibre then informed Vodafone that the work was **on hold** and requested that Vodafone obtain clarification from me to ensure all parties were agreeable to proceed. My neighbour confirmed that his complaint was solely about the key-cutting incident and did not pertain to the work itself.4) Vodafone misunderstood or mismanaged this request and cancelled my order without contacting me for clarification.5) I contacted City Fibre, who confirmed they never requested the cancellation. They read their notes verbatim, with timestamps, and reiterated that they needed Vodafone's instruction to proceed.**From my perspective, the solution was straightforward. The City Fibre engineer had already completed the initial phase of the installation and only needed to complete the work in my flat. All that was needed was for Vodafone to contact City Fibre to confirm that no neighbour requested the work to stop. However, Vodafone chose not to take these steps, even though I had arranged time off work for the installation on 8th November 2024.**---Over two days, I spent countless hours calling Vodafone, navigating automated systems and speaking to service advisors who told me they could not reverse the cancellation or directly contact City Fibre. Vodafone repeatedly blamed City Fibre, while City Fibre stated they could only act on Vodafone's instructions. This lack of transparency and ownership left me in the middle, managing the coordination myself.**Additional Frustrations**- Service advisors directed me to place a new order on the website, which I did, only for it to be cancelled again at 11:26 on Wednesday, 6th November 2024.- Most service advisors refused to transfer me to the "home broadband" team until one agent eventually did. This agent promised to expedite the issue with City Fibre and follow up with a call between 17:30 and 18:30 the next evening but failed to do so.- I had to contact Vodafone again, and after extensive discussions, an advisor escalated the issue but could not connect me to a manager, resulting in another 24-hour wait for a callback.- A manager called on Thursday, 7th November 2024, only to inform me that their only option was to raise another formal complaint, adding another day to the process.- Shaiana from customer care called the following day, not to discuss my complaint but only to transfer me back to the "home broadband" team, where a third order was placed over the phone, which was subsequently cancelled on Tuesday, 12th November 2024.**Update**I have been contacted by Vodafone Customer Care, who advised that "City Fibre requires up to 120 days to obtain permission" to complete the work. However, the agent was unable to clarify what specific permission is needed. This statement directly contradicts City Fibre, who have already completed the initial phase of the installation and were scheduled to finish the work within my flat.Vodafone has also confirmed that they cannot provide interim broadband and no longer offer broadband services that are not Full Fibre. As I cannot wait 120 days without an internet service provider, Vodafone has effectively left me with no choice but to take my business elsewhere.
